exercises.setup_notes: Sit down at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs.
exercises.execution_notes: Grip the bar with a wide grip, pull the bar down to your upper chest while keeping your back straight, and then slowly return to the starting position.
exercises.tier_reasons: Offers a big stretch on your lats, provides smooth even tension throughout the range of motion, feels great, and allows for easy overload by increasing the pin weight.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets both the lats and mid traps due to the wide grip and pulling motion.
exercises.selection_reason: This exercise is selected as it's an S-tier exercise for back development, targeting both lats and mid traps, which are major back muscles.  The wide grip variation allows for a good stretch and even tension throughout the movement, making it suitable for early beginners.  It's also machine-based, ensuring good form and safety for beginners.

exercises.setup_notes: Use a chest-supported row machine or incline bench.
exercises.execution_notes: Pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your chest against the pad, and return to the starting position.
exercises.tier_reasons: Stable, allows focus on back muscles, and can be done with various equipment.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Targets both lats and midback due to the pulling motion.
exercises.additional_notes: Crowned as the best exercise for back development.
exercises.selection_reason: This S-tier exercise is chosen for its focus on back muscles, particularly lats and mid-back. The chest support provides stability, crucial for beginners maintaining proper form.  It's a compound movement, efficient for time constraints, and allows for progressive overload.

exercises.setup_notes: Use a preacher bench to angle your upper arm.
exercises.execution_notes: Ensure full range of motion by going all the way down and maintaining high tension in the stretched position.
exercises.tier_reasons: High tension in stretched position, locks elbows to prevent cheating, significant distal biceps growth.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Distal biceps, due to high tension in stretched position.
exercises.scientific_insights: Study shows preacher curls cause more distal biceps growth compared to incline curls.
exercises.selection_reason: This S-tier exercise is ideal for beginners due to its focus on the biceps and the controlled movement provided by the preacher bench.  It promotes good form and minimizes the risk of injury, while maximizing tension in the stretched position for optimal growth.

exercises.execution_notes: Use a neutral grip with thumbs up.
exercises.tier_reasons: Targets brachialis, enhances bicep peak appearance.
exercises.selection_reason: Including hammer curls targets the brachialis, a muscle that sits underneath the biceps and contributes to overall arm size and definition. The neutral grip helps to isolate the brachialis and prevent overworking the biceps, which is important for balanced development.

warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Extend arms to the sides and make small circles forward for 30 seconds, then backward for 30 seconds.

warmup_exercises.setup_notes: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Slowly rotate your shoulders forward in a circular motion for 30 seconds, then backward for 30 seconds.

warmup_exercises.setup_notes: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hands on hips.
warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Slowly twist your torso from side to side, focusing on controlled movements. Repeat for 30 seconds.

warmup_exercises.setup_notes: Start on your hands and knees.
warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Inhale, drop your belly towards the floor, and lift your chest and tailbone (cow pose). Exhale, round your spine towards the ceiling, tuck your chin to your chest (cat pose). Repeat for 30 seconds.
Gently pull your arm closer to your body using your other hand. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat on the other side. Repeat 2 times.
